newsitem.title: UK: IRA says has left landmine near Belfast castle.
newsitem.headline: IRA says has left landmine near Belfast castle.

text.p: The Irish Republican Army said on Tuesday it had abandoned a land mine in the grounds of a hotel on the outskirts of Belfast, security sources said.

They said a telephone caller using an IRA identity-codeword contacted a local media outlet to say that the device was in a van in the grounds of Belfast Castle, a 19th century former mansion set in extensive parkland.
The caller said the device had been abandoned there because of a high level of security force activity in the district.
British army bomb disposal experts have been called to the castle to examine a suspect vehicle and people attending a function at the castle have been evacuated, police said.
The security sources said that they did not know whether the late night New Year's Eve warning was genuine or a device to lure them into an attack.
They said that the use of the term "abandon" could mean that guerrilla plans of an attack marking the start of the New Year had been thwarted.
Security has been stepped up across Northern Ireland and in mainland Britain since the IRA abandoned a ceasefire last February in a 27-year campaign to end British rule.
The IRA set off a wave of bombs in British cities and killed a soldier at British army headquarters south of Belfast last October.

Tension has heightened in recent weeks with bomb attacks aimed at republicans which security sources believe were reprisals by pro-British Loyalist extremists who have been operating a truce for the last two years.
